newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka says to allow lubricants imports soon.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka says to allow lubricants imports soon.

text.p: Sri Lanka's lubricating oil market will soon be opened to competition by allowing free imports, ending the market monopoly of a local subsidiary of the U.S. oil giant Caltex, a senior government official said on Tuesday.

"Within the next two months we want to call for expressions of interest and license a limited number of suppliers of reputed international brands," said Mano Tittawella, director general of the Public Enterprise Reform Commission (PERC), which oversees privatisations.
Lanka Lubricants Ltd, the Caltex subsidiary, was the sole importer of lubricants into Sri Lanka until April 1, 1997, when its monopoly ended.
Analysts, however, said new entrants will have a tough time due to a 20 percent duty levied on imported lubricating oils and the headstart by Lanka Lubricants, which now blends its product locally.

"Lanka Lubricants also has a contract under which the state-owned Ceylon Petroleum Corporation's 1,000-odd service stations in the country, can sell only its products," said an analyst with a local brokerage.
"The company now has virtually all of the local market of about 26,000 tonnes annually. It has also started exporting and exports will probably take up any slack created by competition," he added.
Lanka Lubricants officials declined to comment.
Lanka Lubricants was privatised by selling 51 percent to Caltex, a joint venture between U.S. oil giants Chevron Corp and Texaco Inc, in 1994.
